head.title: Ease the Race Through the Transit Maze

hedline.hl1: Ease the Race Through the Transit Maze

abstract.p: Katharne Flanders Mukherji letter, commenting on Oct 4 article, says that while defining lateness of subways and buses is important, even more important is the inadequate number of trains and buses at all times but rush hour; drawing

block.p: Re ''When 3 Minutes Late Is On Time: New Transit Agency Standards Raise Questions of Fairness'' (news article, Oct. 4):
While defining lateness is important, even more important is the inadequate number of trains and buses at all times but rush hours.
Re ''When 3 Minutes Late Is On Time: New Transit Agency Standards Raise Questions of Fairness'' (news article, Oct. 4):
While defining lateness is important, even more important is the inadequate number of trains and buses at all times but rush hours.

Riders on most lines experience standing-room-only at almost all times of day: midmorning, early afternoon, midnight, 8 a.m. Saturday, Sunday afternoons and evenings -- not to mention the afternoon school rush hour, which is almost as busy as the evening rush.
No wonder riders run madly for trains and then hold the doors for others; they don't know when the next train may arrive.
Waits of 15 and 30 minutes are too long!

Instead of giving up on hoping for a quality system, we should insist on frequent service at all times. Then, perhaps, fewer people would drive cars in the city, and buses would be less subject to bunching.
